title: Monday, 5th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Urg.

BE11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily you know. This thing.

BE11:03am

Portrait wise, let's start with something practical.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

BE11:04am

That's Natixis's Italian refere .... oh, wait, there's more.

BE11:04am

11:04 am
BE11:04am

That's Natixis's Italian referendum survival guide.

BE11:05am

What I make from it is that Italy's McGuffin referendum has delivered a definitive result -- albeit "definitive" does not imply that it makes any kind of sense.

BE11:06am

The gist here, I think, is there's about a 70% probability of a new technocratic government, to tide us through

11:07 am
BE11:07am

President Mattarella needs to find a centrist who'll keep the right wing happy -- albeit it's a right wing that's just voted against their own interests constitutionally to turn the poll into a defacto confidence vote of ..... oh, bloody hell.

BE11:08am

Let me get some sellside.

BE11:08am

Goldman

11:08 am
BE11:08am

The rejection of the Constitutional amendments does not represent an institutional trauma. Indeed, the architecture of the Italian State will remain as it has been since 1948. What is more relevant for market participants are the political scenarios that open up from here. Our Economists’ base case remains that a transition government will be in place until the next general election
in early 2018. This is how our Economists see the political situation evolving:

BE11:08am

· This afternoon, PM Renzi will formally tender his resignations to the President of the Republic, Mr Mattarella. The latter will likely ask Mr Renzi to stay on to preside over the approval of the 2017 Budget Law – the deadline for which is 31 December. Meanwhile the President will officially start consultations with leaders of the political forces represented in Parliament for the formation of a new government.

BE11:08am

· Our Economists’ base case is that the current ruling coalition will continue to stick together and back a new government. As not all of PD’s leadership supported the referendum, the political fallout is likely to be mostly within the party, rather than altering political balances.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

· Our Economists have elevated their subjective probability of a caretaker government from 45% to 60%. They expect the Cabinet to be led by a political figure drawn from the ranks of the ruling coalition (one possibility is the Minister of the Economy Padoan). The new government would likely have a limited policy agenda consisting mainly of: (i) Overseeing the recapitalization of the partly state-owned Monte dei Paschi di Siena and potentially other smaller banks; and (ii) re-drafting the electoral laws for the two Chambers of Parliament ahead of a general election in early 2018.

· We have raised our subjective odds from 20% to 25%, but not higher.

BE11:09am

Banks, tho?

BE11:09am

Not in that much trouble.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Here's the Credit Suisse exposure graph.

BE11:09am

BE11:10am

SO, clearly, Barclays is up.

11:10 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 217.55, up 4.6 (+2.16%), High: 220.45, Low: 210.50, Volume: 18.21m
BE11:10am

And local ones mostly steady. Though "steady at nearly zero" isn't really steady, one could argue.

BE11:11am

Credit Suisse text incoming.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

[W]e believe the market has not fully priced in the hard ‘No’ into European Banks post outperforming by c.10% over the past 3m. Italian Banks have underperformed by 13%, and the 10 year Italian sovereign spread has widened by c.80bp vs the Bund since mid August. European Banks trade at c.0.95x TBV, 2017E and the implied COE at 8.6% is not elevated (is at the bottom-end of the 8.5-10.5% range seen since 2013).

BE11:11am

■ The next step. The PM, Matteo Renzi looks set to step down, and to try to ensure continuity President Mattarella could try to endorse current Finance Minister Pier Carlo Padoan to form a new government. Given the lack of a supportive majority this could prove difficult. Early elections could create further uncertainty, but CS Economists note that 'The economic and policy backdrop is better than it was during the sovereign crisis of 2011-13: GDP growth is weak but at least back into positive territory, the global economy is on a recovery path...', ‘Italian Referendum – No is No?’, 1 Dec., 2016.

BE11:11am

■ The No vote – negative for bank equity, but contagion risk could be limited. We do not see meaningful funding risks for the sector as there are numerous tools for the ECB to support banks; the sector has EUR3.8tn in free collateral, or c.14% of total assets, CSe. European Banks’ exposure to Italy is relatively limited and amounts to c.EUR385bn total credit exposure, equal to c.1.8% of the total (EBA, 2015 data). Names with relatively higher credit exposure to Italy are; BNP (N, TP EUR55) c.9.7% of total exposure, Group Credit Agricole (unlisted) c.6.0%, Belfius (unlisted) c.3.5%, CBK (NC) c.3.3%, DBK (UP TP EUR 13) c.3.0% and ING (NC) c.2.5%. We believe that banks have already cut exposures to Italian counterparties and European Banks’ exposure to Italian banks is only c.0.1-0.2% of total credit exposure, CSe.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

■ Broader sector risks: 1) political contagion with anti-establishment parties gaining support (French Presidential election, 2017), and 2) if recapitalisation efforts fail and a bail-in scenario emerges for Italian banks. We expect UCG (N, TP EUR2.3) to announce a EUR10-13bn rights issue on its Strategy Day, 13 December. Raising c.90% of m-cap is already a difficult task and the political uncertainty is unhelpful, see details in 'Italian Banks, Next stop: Italian Referendum', 21 November, 2016.

BE11:11am

■ Stock calls. We continue to favour banks with strong capital and structural (fee/CEE) growth. Well capitalised names where CS is above consensus dividends are, Danske (all-in yield, c.8.1%), Natixis (c.7.5%) and Nordea (c.6.8%), 2017E. We argue banks geared to Wholesale/Investment banking could struggle: SEB (UP, TP SEK73) and DB. POP’s (UP, TP EUR0.7) profitability is impaired by its high exposure to Spanish property.

BE11:12am

And Citi ......

11:11 am
BE11:12am

What Does Not Kill You Makes You Stronger
We expect banks’ share prices to react negatively to the referendum results, and to suffer a period of enhanced volatility. However, we believe that spreads asset quality capital increases are the fundamental driver of banks’ valuation long term, and those do not depend solely on political developments. Ultimately we believe that for long-term investors (happy to face the volatility) there is value in the banks in our active coverage, as the needed restructuring could result in a more solid banking sector with valuation reversing to fundamental (the sharp YTD de-rating is mostly due to fear/ high risk premium).

BE11:12am

Short-Term Impact
Italian banks have de-rated significantly and already trade at a discount vs. long-term averages. However we expect increased volatility over the next several days for sovereign risk premium and banks’ share prices, also while awaiting newsflow on bank capital increases, ECB, and political development.

BE11:12am

Spread is in the ECB Hands
The next ECB meeting (8th December) is key for banks and our economists expect a very accommodative monetary stance, and potentially a 6-month extension of the asset purchase programme (How Best to Set a Soft ECB Taper Course?). Spread expansion is a key risk for Italian banks.
Capital Increases Challenging
We believe that announced capital rebuilds could be challenging to complete in this volatile environment. The pending UniCredit restructuring/potential capital increase (to be announced on 13th December) could be still be surrounded by volatility/completion risk, and this could affect also company decisions (alternatives / size?). Nevertheless, as it could go live in a few months (February 2017?), there could be many possible political developments by then, and our base case is that it could feasible (depending also on the size).

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Negative Impact on European Banks
While the referendum results should not significantly impact the Italian operations of European banks, it is likely to increase fear over political risk in Europe and negatively weight on banks valuation. Italian banks valuations reflect distressed conditions/high fears, while this is not the case for all European banks (figure 4). French banks could be among the most vulnerable (relatively high exposure to Italy and political risk with election 2017, Exposure To Italy Pre-Referendum – France in the Spotlight), together with high beta names. Among the least affected could be defensive banks like Danske/Nordic.

BE11:13am

Or if all that's too much to read, here's Deutsche's one par summary.

BE11:13am

The referendum was a catalyst rather than the cause of Italy’s complex situation. The complexity is due to disappointing growth, concerns about the banking system and the rise of populist and euro-sceptic parties. At least initially, we do not expect to revise down our GDP projections as the “No” outcome was our central case scenario. The likelihood of a systemic solution for the NPL issue will influence the medium-term evolution of the Italian banking sector and banks’ ability to support investment growth. We expect no pro-active systemic solution for the banking sector before the next election. We expect a new electoral law for both Houses of the Parliament. In our opinion, it is important that a compromise on a new electoral law does not lead to a system that encourages the formation of governments supported by overly heterogeneous coalitions.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

There you go.

undefined
BE11:14am

(@JDB75: where did you read that?)

11:14 am
BE11:15am

And so, to London. Equities up, gold down, not a lot happening.

BE11:15am

FTSE ahead 0.4%, up 27 points at 6757 or thereabouts.

BE11:16am

Burberry probably the most interesting of the risers.

11:15 am
Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,447, up 35 (+2.48%), High: 1,455, Low: 1,420, Volume: 706.43k
BE11:16am

Which is post Arash doing a bit of story archaeology.

BE11:16am

https://www.ft.com...-8b45-b8b81dd5d080

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Burberry, the UK’s biggest luxury goods retailer, rejected multiple takeover overtures from US fashion accessories group Coach in recent months, according to people briefed on the matter.

A deal would have created a group with a market value above $20bn, bringing together the US company’s leather goods, handbags and shoemaker Stuart Weitzman with Burberry’s trademark luxury outerwear and global retail footprint.

Talks are no longer active between the companies and that is not expected to change anytime soon after Burberry saw off the interest from its larger rival, these people added. Burberry and Coach declined to comment.

BE11:17am

You'll remember this one going around.

BE11:18am

We were on it. https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-10-21/ ... Ben was on it ..... https://www.betavi...ry-merger-sources/

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Wires did their usual "phone the flack and get a present-tense denial," thing.

BE11:20am

Now, to be absolutely clear, there's nothing currently going on here. And I'm getting rather mixed messages about how serious the early exchanges between the companies were.

BE11:20am

But as we always say at these times, it's worth emphasising that the journalists are always the last to know.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

The hot money gets in long before the stories reach us.

BE11:20am

Then what happens is that the people involved lie.

BE11:21am

Lie their faces off. Shameless, lying liars.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And as a result, the market stays crooked.

BE11:21am

In this case, timings are all a bit vague. We're unclear whether the approach was live or dead when we picked it up.

BE11:21am

Don't know whether the reports forced a pens down, or whether it was already dead.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

What I would note, though, is Burberry's continuing buyback.

BE11:22am

As per ......

BE11:22am

http://www.londons...BRBY/12898761.html

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Burberry has entered into a non-discretionary instruction with Morgan Stanley & Co. International Plc ("Morgan Stanley") in relation to the purchase by Morgan Stanley, acting as principal during the period commencing on 20 July 2016 and ending no later than 18 April 2017, of Ordinary Shares in the Company's share capital (the "Shares") for an aggregate purchase price of no greater than £100m and the simultaneous on-sale of such Shares by Morgan Stanley to Burberry.
Any purchase of Ordinary Shares done in relation to this announcement will be carried out on the London Stock Exchange and executed in accordance with the Listing Rules and Burberry's general authority to make market purchases of Shares. Burberry will announce any market repurchase of Ordinary Shares no later than 7.30 a.m. on the business day following the calendar day on which the repurchase occurred. To the extent permitted by law, Ordinary Shares purchased under the Programme will be held in treasury.

BE11:23am

(@SoS: when someone speaks to you off the record, you can't breach that confidence even if they're lying. Standard rules of engagement. If we break those, we're no better than the lying lairs.)

BE11:24am

Okay, so I'm not a lawyer. I'm unclear if that disclaimer gives Morgan Stanley carte blanche to buy Burberry stock even when Burberry's board is sitting on price-sensitive information.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Which has possibly leaked into the market.

BE11:24am

Dunno. Open to opinions here.

BE11:26am

............. Oh, hey, and just as a postscript ........

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Remember that story near the start of the year that there was a mystery stakebuilder in Burberry and they'd brought in Robey Warshaw? The one that got a bit muddled in the publishing process, then quite a few other news outlets took the p___ out of mercilessly when HSBC denied it was acting for one client?

BE11:28am

Well ................ Censored

undefined
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Miners were mentioned earlier, weren't they?

BE11:29am

Citi's pushing the sector.

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 712.00, up 18.5 (+2.67%), High: 714.50, Low: 697.00, Volume: 601.75k
11:29 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,328, up 23.5 (+1.80%), High: 1,343, Low: 1,314, Volume: 2.12m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,048, up 42.5 (+1.41%), High: 3,086, Low: 3,034, Volume: 1.42m
BE11:02am

Right. Let's get this started, why don't we.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

They've stayed on the sidelines while the sector rose 100% YTD, but are now ready to turn bullish.

BE11:30am

After a decade or so of the mining industry defending its dysfunctional behavior (high capex and running for volume over value) we think that there are enough signs that there is an alteration in behavior which could lead to value creation for the companies over the next few years. Therefore we are upgrading our sector view from bearish to bullish.

BE11:30am

The industry is going through a period of change with behaviors changing on the demand and supply side. On the demand side, it had paid to be long what China was short (copper, iron ore) but China now appears committed to cutting capacity in over-capacity industries we therefore argue that over the next few years it is likely to pay to be long sectors China is rationalizing, such as steel and coal. Moreover fiscal stimulus measures are mounting in OECD countries and this is all pointing towards global growth in US$, which has historically been favorable for commodity demand. On the supply side, there are indications that the mining companies appear to be holding the line, and will run for value over volume, leading to anemic volume growth outlook on our forecasts.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The key reasons driving our changes is a more robust outlook for 2017 for the commodity complex, especially the bulks, which is leading to cash flow and earnings upgrades along with higher forecasted dividend yields. Moreover, short term, commodity prices have been firmer for longer this year which has resulted in substantial balance sheet repair for the miners. The miners also appear to be holding down capex for longer and the inflation pressures that we expected to build are being cushioned by weaker producer currencies against a stronger US$ which is proving to be a fillip for the companies.

BE11:30am

While uncertainty likely dominates the global economy in 2017, commodities should continue to perform well, Price volatility should accompany the fits and starts of market re-balancing and should be given an extra lift from Chinese domestic policies having unintended consequences on global commodity markets. Our global commodities team have made changes to their commodity price outlook in particular to the bulk commodities. This has resulted in material earnings, cash flow and NPV upgrades for the sector.

BE11:31am

We are upgrading BHP Billiton and South32 to Buy from Sell; Glencore and Lundin Mining to Buy from Neutral; Rio Tinto and Anglo American to Neutral from Sell. In base metals we upgrade Boliden and Nyrstar to Neutral from Sell. We have Buy ratings on KAZ Minerals and Sell on Fresnillo, Acacia and Ferrexpo.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

(@Icarus: I'm neither. I'm a hack.)

BE11:32am

Want some incomprehensible graphs with that?

BE11:32am

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 276.93, down 0.97 (-0.35%), High: 285.00, Low: 275.50, Volume: 15.18m
Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 1,155, down 43 (-3.59%), High: 1,202, Low: 1,149, Volume: 464.49k
11:33 am
BE11:34am

.............. etc.

undefined
BE11:36am

Mondays are the worst, right? Have a brief midsession off-topic break.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

With this story about a goat: http://www.carrick...nd-store-1-7711772

BE11:37am

BE11:37am

Thumbs up Caption.

11:37 am
undefined
BE11:37am

Okay, back to news.

BE11:37am

Topps mentioned.

11:37 am
Topps Tiles PLC (TPT:LSE): Last: 84.50, down 3.25 (-3.70%), High: 91.50, Low: 83.00, Volume: 363.23k
BE11:38am

http://www.investe...1612051106179714Q/

BE11:38am

Further to the announcement of its annual financial results for the 52 weeks ended 1 October 2016 on 29 November 2016, the Group has discovered an error in the calculation of the like-for-like sales figure for the first eight weeks of the new financial year, such that like-for-like sales in the period were -0.3% and not +0.8% as previously stated.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

........... Uh, that's quite a difference.

BE11:40am

And if I remember right, the 0.8% figure was below expectations anyway.

BE11:41am

Now, without further info I can imagine how this happened.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Topps closed its wood flooring business in the period

BE11:42am

Still ........ Anyway, elsewhere in smalls.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 123.55, up 18.3 (+17.39%), High: 130.00, Low: 102.25, Volume: 631.51k
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Everything's fine! Your concerns about online estate agents using a rather punchy agent model in a slowing market are entirely misplaced!

BE11:44am

H1 delivers us a maiden profit and some rather defensive stuff about completing sales.

BE11:45am

(Maiden profit on the core UK business, I mean. The rest of it's still burning cash.)

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here's Citi ......

BE11:45am

Purplebricks reported solid 1H17 interims, with revenues in line with our expectations. Headline adj. EBITDA was below our estimates due to cost investment in Australia. The UK had a strong revenue performance as the brand gained traction, supporting Purplebricks achieving its maiden profit result as scale benefits in the business model showed through. The trading outlook for the 2H remains strong, with similar YoY growth, despite the sector headwinds and seasonality. Management reiterated that they are on track to meet internal expectations for FY17 (Citi FY17e Revenues £43.9m; Consensus £42.3m; Citi adj. EBITDA of -£7.8m driven by £7.0m loss in Australia; Consensus -£1.1m).

BE11:45am

1H17 result highlights the leverage in the business model, with the UK division achieving a maiden positive EBITDA result. Management remains confident to meet expectations for FY17e. We expect no changes to consensus at this stage.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

We recently initiated with a Buy/High Risk rating and 200p price target. The stock is trading at CY18E PE of 37.2x, PEG ratio of 0.44x and EV/Sales of 4.0x .

BE11:46am

Average revenue per customer up +20% to £1k .........

BE11:47am

Instructions up 108% to 17,200

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Peel Hunt reckons that's a UK market share of c2.2%, twice what it was.

BE11:48am

Agent numbers increasing at the same pace ......

BE11:48am

As in, up 119% to 329.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

As to the wounded stuff ......

BE11:48am

Purplebricks sells homes. We were never in any doubt that Purplebricks sells the homes that it lists. One reason for our confidence is that the group consistently receives strong ratings from its customers on Trustpilot with an average ‘excellent’ rating (scoring 9.4 out of 10). To fully debunk any myths the group has carried out an extensive exercise verifying over 11,600 homes that were marked as Sold Subject to Contract on the property portals. The Land Registry has confirmed that c90% of the sample has been registered as sold (with the remainder exchanged, completed but not yet registered on the Land Registry or back on the market). In the UK approximately 1.6m homes are listed for sale each year, with c75% (1.2m) progressing to sale. Against this figure, Purplebricks compares very favourably. Purplebricks unequivocally sells homes. Case closed.

BE11:48am

Wait, no.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

That's not "case closed".

BE11:49am

It'd only be "case closed" if PurpleBricks could give us data on the number of transactions moving from "sold Subject to contract" to "sold" without another estate agent getting involved.

BE11:49am

It's no surprise whatsoever that nine out of ten sold properties are sold. In fact, it's pretty disappointing given ten out of ten of those properties were sold STC.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

(And that total market figure of "three-quarters of listed properties are sold" is completely irrelevant in this context.)

BE11:50am

As for the TrustPilot reviews ... well, have a look yourself.

BE11:50am

https://uk.trustpi...w/purplebricks.com

11:50 am
BE11:50am

It's mostly folk talking about how quick they've sold the house.

BE11:50am

Such as ...

BE11:50am

11:50 am
BE11:51am

... which is great! But everyone knows you don't sell a house in six days.

BE11:51am

An agent might find a willing buyer by then, but in the current Purplebricks payment regime that agent has no incentive whatsoever to confirm the the buyer can actually buy.

BE11:51am

You'll also note that the review above -- in common with about half of them -- was submitted at the request of PurpleBricks.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

So, when's that request to review made?

BE11:51am

At the sale, or at the sale STC?

BE11:52am

Anyway. Back to Peel Hunt.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Forecast and valuation. While we expect the UK residential market to be slower next year, we also expect Purplebricks to continue to grow share. Overall, we have reduced our near term forecasts to reflect the slower outlook for the UK market and the group’s planned increased marketing spend. Our 2018 EPS forecast has reduced to 2.4p (from 3.6p) and our 2019 EPS to 8.7p (from 9.2p).

BE11:52am

Our new target price of 270p (previously 300p) still offers very significant upside. Momentum in the business remains strong and we maintain our Buy recommendation.

BE11:54am

Anthony Codling at Jefferies is of course the person who's done most work on Purplebricks' completition ratios. His response is ...... terse.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We look forward in due course to Purplebricks matching the disclosures of traditional agents by disclosing how many homes they sell.

BE11:54am

Hm.

undefined
11:56 am
BE11:56am

ROTR: all your Brexit Supreme Court needs are met here: https://www.ft.com...-ba85-95d1533d9a62

BE11:57am

And then again here, from Jolyon Maugham QC: https://ftalphavil...the-supreme-court/

BE11:58am

Do make sure to read the latter. It's clear, informed and sensible.

11:58 am
undefined
BE12:01pm

.......... And that's midday. We made it. Somehow.

BE12:01pm

Thanks for all the comments. Do please come back tomorrow, in spite of today.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Afternoon all.

Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 385.50, up 10.2 (+2.72%), High: 386.80, Low: 374.80, Volume: 594.37k
